name: Q-Tip (musician)
description:
'''Kamaal Ibn John Fareed''' (born '''Jonathan William Davis''', April 10, 1970), better known by his stage name '''Q-Tip''', is an American rapper, record producer, singer, and DJ. Nicknamed '''the Abstract''', he is noted for his innovative [[jazz rap|jazz-influenced]] style of [[Hip-hop production|hip hop production]] and his philosophical, esoteric and introspective lyrical themes. He embarked on his music career in the late 1980s, as an [[master of ceremonies#Hip hop|MC]] and main producer of the influential [[Alternative hip-hop|alternative hip hop]] group [[A Tribe Called Quest]]. In the mid-1990s, he co-founded the production team [[The Ummah]], followed by the release of his [[Recording Industry Association of America certification|gold]]-certified solo debut ''[[Amplified (Q-Tip album)|Amplified]]'' in 1999. In the following decade, he released the [[Grammy Award]]-nominated album ''[[The Renaissance (Q-Tip album)|The Renaissance]]'' (2008) and the experimental album ''[[Kamaal the Abstract]]'' (2009).

As an actor, Q-Tip has appeared in various films, such as ''[[Poetic Justice (film)|Poetic Justice]]'', ''[[She Hate Me]]'', and ''[[Prison Song (film)|Prison Song]]'', the latter of which he co-wrote and played the lead role. As a DJ, he has hosted the [[Apple Music 1]] radio show ''Abstract Radio'' since 2015. In 2016, Q-Tip was named the artistic director for [[Hip-hop culture|hip hop culture]] at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]], and in 2018, he became the instructor of a jazz and hip hop course at [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts|Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music]].

Q-Tip is one of the most acclaimed figures in hip hop. [[AllMusic]] states that he "led a jazz-based hip-hop revolution during the '90s", calling him "the best rapper/producer in hip-hop history". Several publications have ranked him as one of the greatest rappers and hip hop producers of all time, with ''[[The Source (magazine)|The Source]]'' ranking him the 20th greatest rap lyricist, and ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' ranking him the sixth greatest hip hop producer. In 2024, Q-Tip was inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]], as a member of A Tribe Called Quest.
